Detailed Description

A block coordinate (COO) format sparse matrix.

Note:
This data structure is suited for low amortized cost of dynamic addition of entries, but isn't necessarily as space-efficient as it could be.

Field Documentation

int bcoo_matrix_t::bm

Number of block rows

int bcoo_matrix_t::bn

Number of block columns

int bcoo_matrix_t::c

Number of columns in each dense subblock

int bcoo_matrix_t::col_oriented_p

0 if the values in each nonzero block are stored row-oriented, 1 if column-oriented. If value_type==PATTERN, then this field is ignored.

void(* bcoo_matrix_t::deallocator)(void *)

Function for deallocating the input arrays, if LIBRARY_DEALLOCATES.

int* bcoo_matrix_t::II

For block e, II[e] is the actual (not block) row index of the upper left corner of the block (we can't call the array "I" because that is reserved as a macro in C99 for sqrt{-1}).

enum index_base_t bcoo_matrix_t::index_base

Base of indexing (either one or zero)

int* bcoo_matrix_t::JJ

For block e, JJ[e] is the actual (not block) column index of the upper left corner of the block.

int bcoo_matrix_t::nnzb

Number of stored (nonzero) blocks. If the matrix is stored in a symmetric (or skew, etc.) format, nnz only refers to the number of stored blocks, not the actual number of nonzero blocks.

int bcoo_matrix_t::nnzb_upper_bound

Maximum number of stored (nonzero) blocks that the data structure can currently hold. Invariant: nnzb <= nnzb_upper_bound.

enum ownership_mode_t bcoo_matrix_t::ownership

Indicates who is responsible for deallocating the input arrays.

int bcoo_matrix_t::r

Number of rows in each dense subblock

enum symmetric_storage_location_t bcoo_matrix_t::symmetric_storage_location

If the matrix has a kind of symmetry (or skew-symmetry): Where the actual elements of the matrix are stored: in the lower triangle or the upper triangle.

enum symmetry_type_t bcoo_matrix_t::symmetry_type

Symmetry type of the matrix.

void* bcoo_matrix_t::val

For entry e, val[r*c*e : r*c*e + r*c - 1] holds its values. Type of the entries depends on the value of value_type. If value_type == PATTERN, then val is NULL (and holds nothing).

enum value_type_t bcoo_matrix_t::value_type

Indicates the type of the entries in val: REAL means "double", COMPLEX means "double _Complex", PATTERN means the "val" array is NULL and contains no entries.
